This MahÄsaá¹ƒnipÄta SÅ«tra has a total of 100,000 gÄthÄs.

It is seen that the translator Tripiá¹­aka Master JÃ±Änagupta often said:
More than 2,000 li southeast of Khotan,
there is the country of CÄgÄ.
The king there has pure faith and respect for the MahÄyÄna.
All famous monks from other countries who enter his territory are all tested.
If they study the HÄ«nayÄna, they are sent away and not kept.
Those of the MahÄyÄna are invited to stay and receive offerings.
The royal palace itself has the three great sÅ«tras of MahÄprajÃ±Ä, MahÄsaá¹ƒnipÄta, and Avatamsaka,
all of which are one hundred thousand gÄthÄs.
However, as the time since the Sage's passing grows distant,
ordinary beings' awareness gradually dims and they are unable to fully uphold [the teachings].
They compile and write according to their abilities.
As a result, the original Sanskrit texts are incomplete.
They are abbreviated into five abridged translations.
The extensive ones are translated extensively.
For this reason, the earlier sages such as Zhi and Tan translated,
and KumÄrajÄ«va produced,
either twenty-seven,ğŸ”½or thirty,
or thirty-one scrolls.
The scrolls are not fixed.
Whenever it is proclaimed, it is always laughed and sighed over.
During the Gao-Qi period, Ya-she
produced the Moon Treasury SÅ«tra in twelve scrolls.
Up to the present Kai-huang period, it is again entrusted to Ya-she to translate the Sun Treasury SÅ«tra in fifteen scrolls.
Since they are both based on the Great Collection, the old chapters within,
are truly joyful and leaping.
They are immediately combined to form sixty scrolls.
